Graphical abstract The catalytic performance of small Pd-nanoparticles (NPs) (2.0nm), partially covered by chemisorbed oxygen atoms, and of Pd-acetate, both stabilized by 2,2′-bipyridine-end functionalized poly(ethyleneglycol) monomethylether was compared in the selective hydration of nitriles to amide in water under mild reaction conditions (353K). Regardless of the nitrile substrate employed, the Pd-NP-based catalyst showed much higher normalized TON-values (i.e. refereeing to the amount of surface Pd atoms) compared to the Pd(II) macrocomplex, as far as the first catalytic run was considered. Deactivation of the Pd-NP-based catalyst was significant due to the formation of a hydroxide-water layer on the NPs’ surface. Keywords Poly(ethyleneglycol) Nitriles Amides Palladium Nanoparticles 1 Introduction Amide bonds are fundamental for the composition of biologically active systems, since they are the key link between amino acids in proteins. Moreover many marketed drug molecules contain amide bonds [1,2], for instance Atorvastatin [3], a top selling drug worldwide which blocks the production of cholesterol or Diltiazem a calcium channel blocker used for treatment of angina and hypertension [4]. The majority of amide bond syntheses involve the use of stoichiometric amounts of coupling reagents [5], making this approach expensive and not sustainable from an environmental point of view. Hence atom-efficient catalytic amide bond forming reactions are highly desired [6]. Four different types of metal-catalyzed primary amide synthesis procedures of relevance have been described, namely: (i) the dehydrogenative coupling of primary alcohols with ammonia in water [7–9]; (ii) the primary amide synthesis from aldoximes or aldehydes [10,11]; (iii) the palladium-catalyzed aminocarbonylation of halide compounds either in the presence of ammonia [12] or formamide [13] and (iv) the metal catalyzed hydration of nitriles [14] in the homogeneous [15,16] and heterogeneous phases [17–24], with [25] and without the presence of metal nanoparticles (NPs) [26–28]. Excellent homogenous catalysts for this latter reaction were designed based on the concept of bifunctional catalysis, where the metal centre acts as a Lewis acid, activating the nitrile functional group and the ligand as Brønsted base, providing the nucleophilic hydroxide group which attacks the metal-coordinated nitrile group [16,29–31]. This latter catalytic concept has been also applied to heterogeneously-catalyzed nitrile hydration reactions, where the nitrile functional group is activated by the surface atoms of metal NPs and chemisorbed oxygen atoms function as Brønsted base [32–34]. Indeed, it has been found that the percentage of the NPs' oxygen atom coverage is a key parameter for the observed catalytic activity [17,18]. Herein we compare the catalytic performance of small Pd-NPs with that of Pd(OAc)2 (OAc=acetate) in the hydration of nitriles to amide in water. In order to solubilize both catalysts in the reaction medium, we stabilized both Pd-based catalysts with 2,2′-bipyridine end-functionalized poly(ethyleneglycol) (PEG) monomethylether. PEG is an amphiphatic polymer and functions itself as a unique solvent [35,36]. The high water solubility of PEG combined with its insolubility in diethyl ether and hexane was exploited to separate the organic reaction compounds from catalyst. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts The reaction of mesityl–PEG–OMe [37] (i.e. the mesityl functional group is an ideal leaving group for nucleophilic substitution reactions) with 4′-methyl-(2,2′-bipyridine)-4-yl-methanol in the presence of NaH and anhydrous DMF gave after work-up the 2,2′-bipyridine-end-functionalized macroligand BiPy–PEG–OMe (L) as off-white powder in 75% yield (Scheme 1 ). The methoxy-capped PEG gives not undesired side products during the mesitylation reaction step, whereas PEG bearing two terminal OH-groups is prone to inter- and intramolecular nucleophilic substitution reactions in the course of the latter reaction. The successful binding of 4′-methyl-(2,2′-bipyridine)-4-yl to PEG through an ether functional group was proved by 1H NMR and UV–vis spectroscopy conducted in water. The corresponding 1H NMR spectrum showed the presence of signals assigned to the aromatic part of the 2,2′-bipyridine ligand (Fig. 1 , trace a). Accordingly, the UV–vis spectrum of L showed the absorption at 282.5nm and an absorption shoulder at 239.4nm, while PEG does not show any absorption in this region (Fig. 2 ). The reaction of L with one molequivalent of Pd(OAc)2 (OAc=acetate) in CH2Cl2 at room temperature gave a brownish solution from which the macrocomplex [Pd(OAc)2 L] (1) (Scheme 1) was precipitated as brown solid with 72% yield. The lH NMR spectrum (D2O) of Pd(OAc)2 coordinated to the 2,2′-bipyridine unit of the macroligand showed the expected coordination shift of the 2,2′-bipyridine unit (Fig. 1, trace b vs a). In addition the presence of two 1H NMR singlets centered at 1.84 and 1.97ppm confirmed the presence of acetate hydrogen atoms and the lacking symmetry of L. The coordination of Pd(OAc)2 to L caused also a shift of the bipyridine UV–vis absorption bands to higher wavelength. Hence absorption maxima at 311, 302 (shoulder), 247.5nm for 1 have been observed (Fig. 2). The reaction of a CH2Cl2 solution of 1 with hydrogen (15bar) at room temperature for 12h gave a black solution, which upon solvent evaporation and successive washing of the solid obtained with diethyl ether (2×5.0mL) gave the L-stabilized Pd-NPs (2) as dark brown solid with 93% yield. An 1H NMR spectrum of the latter solid, acquired in D2O, showed a clear shift of the 1H NMR signals, assigned to the aromatic 2,2′-bipyridine hydrogen atoms, compared to that of 1 and L (Fig. 1, trace c vs b and a), indicating interactions of the nitrogen atoms of L with the Pd-NP surface [38]. The pattern of the UV–vis spectrum of 2 resembles very much that of 1 with the absorption maxima being lower compared to 1 (Fig. 2). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of 2 confirmed the presence of well-dispersed Pd-NPs characterized by an average particle size (dm ) of 2.09±0.49nm (Fig. 3 ). The Pd-content, determined by induced coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), was of 2.0wt%. The corresponding Pd dispersion, calculated from average particle size obtained from TEM analysis by using the equation d rel(VS) =3.32/FE1.23 [39] (i.e. FE is the fraction of Pd atoms exposed to solution, d rel(VS) = d VS/d at, d VS is the volume-surface mean diameter of an assembly of particles of different sizes, and d at is the atomic diameter of palladium (2.74Å)) revealed to be 51%. The 2,2′-bipyridine end group of L efficiently controls the reduction of Pd(II) to Pd(0) and the successive stabilization of the obtained Pd-NPs. In fact, the reduction of Pd(OAc)2 in the presence of pyridine-end functionalized PEG [40] (i.e. pyridine is less coordinating to Pd(II) and Pd(0) compared 2,2′-bipyridine) or not functionalized PEG give Pd-NPs which is much bigger in size [41]. In accordance with TEM measurements, X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, conducted on isolated 2, showed the presence of Pd(0) (i.e. Pd 3d 5/2 at 334.8eV) [42] and Pd(II) (i.e. Pd 3d 5/2 at 337.1eV) [43] in a 4:1 atom ratio (Fig. 4 a). The binding energies (BE) of Pd(II) correspond to that of chemisorbed oxygen atoms (Oads) on Pd-NPs’ surface [17]. 2.2 Catalytic nitrile hydration reactions 1 and 2 were used to chemoselectively hydrate aromatic and aliphatic nitriles in water in the presence of an air atmosphere to give the corresponding amide as proved by GC–MS analysis. Pd(II) 2,2′-bipyridine complexes [44,45] (i.e. 349K, substrate to Pd molar ratio of 383) as well as Pd-NPs supported onto carbon [17] (i.e. 413K, substrate to Pd molar ratio of 50) have been employed to catalyze the nitrile hydration under completely different experimental conditions. We compare the catalytic performance of both Pd-based catalysts at 353K and a substrate to Pd molar ratio of 56, using the normalized TON value (i.e. TON referred to the Pd atoms exposed to the catalytic solution). The results of the comparative catalytic reactions are compiled in Table 1 . From the catalytic data shown in Table 1, we infer that: (i) regardless of the substrate employed, the Pd-NP-based catalyst showed significantly higher activity in terms of normalized TON (i.e. 1 and 2 have respectively 100% and 51% of the Pd atoms exposed to the catalytic solution. This experimental fact holds also for the nitrile hydration with time as shown for benzonitrile (Table 1, entries 8–12 vs 1–5). The difference in catalytic activity between both catalysts was most pronounced in those cases where a strong substrate coordination to Pd(II) is expected, as for 2- and 4-cyanopyridine (Table 1, entry 20 vs 19 and entry 22 vs 21). (ii) The catalytic activity drop is higher in the case of 2 compared to 1 (Table 1, entries 12–14 vs 5–7). (iii) The addition of one mole equivalent of L to 2 had no beneficial effect on the catalyst performance over three consecutive catalytic reactions (i.e. benzonitrile conversion dropped from 83% to 45% in the first and second recycling experiment, respectively) (Table 1, entry 16 vs 17 and 18). 2.3 Mechanistic investigations 2.3.1 Pd-NP-catalyzed reactions In order to investigate the deactivation mechanism operative in Pd-NP-catalyzed nitrile hydration reactions in water, we isolated the water soluble catalyst upon precipitation with iso-propanol and studied the recovered catalyst by TEM, XPS, and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). TEM micrographs of recovered 2 (i.e. recovered after the first catalytic run) and 2 + L (i.e. recovered after the third catalytic run) (Fig. 5 ) clearly showed a strong aggregation of Pd-NPs in 2 already after the first catalytic run (Fig. 5, left). In contrast, the presence of an additional amount of macroligand L, significantly avoided the NP-aggregation process (Fig. 5, right). This experimental fact is strongly indicating that 2 is in equilibrium with naked Pd-NPs, generated by L dissociation from 2, and L. Naked Pd-NPs strongly aggregate during catalysis, while free L interacts with 2, avoiding hence the aggregation of 2 as proved by the TEM-micrograph of 2 + L (Fig. 5, right). The average Pd-NP size of recovered 2 and 2 + L were of 3.5 and 4.5nm, respectively. XPS spectra acquired on recovered 2 and 2 + L showed the presence of Pd(0) (i.e. Pd 3d 5/2 at 334.2eV) and Pd(II) (i.e. Pd 3d 5/2 BE at 337.7 and 337.4eV). The Pd 3d BE of these latter Pd(II) species are slight shifted to higher energies compared to that observed for either PdO or Pd-NPs covered by chemisorbed oxygen atoms [43,46] (Fig. 4, traces b and c). The shift of the BE is in accordance with the presence of hydroxide ions on the Pd-NPs' surface [47,48] which are stabilized by water molecules through hydrogen bond interactions [49–51]. An increase of the Pd(II)/Pd(0) atom ratio from 2.6:1 (i.e. 2 after the first run, Fig. 4, trace b) to 7:1 (i.e. 2 + L, after the third run, Fig. 4, trace c) is indicative for a continuous coverage of Pd-NPs with a hydroxide-water layer. By combining results obtained from catalytic reactions, TEM and XPS analyses, we propose the following reaction steps operative in 2-catalyzed nitrile hydration in water (Scheme 2 ). The activation of a water molecule is assisted by a surface chemisorbed oxygen atom (Oads), followed by a concerted attack of the coordinated nitrile functional group [17,33,34]. Theoretical calculations confirmed a notable decrease of the water-splitting activation energy when chemisorbed oxygen-assisted [34] compared to a clean Pd surface [32] (i.e. 0.48eV vs 1.12eV). In order to prove the importance of chemi-adsorbed oxygen atoms for the catalytic nitrile hydration, we carried out analogous catalytic reactions in the presence of rigorously deaerated water and a nitrogen atmosphere. As a result, an almost identical substrate conversion was achieved (Table 1, entry 15 vs 12). A much lower substrate conversion in D2O compared to H2O (i.e. TON: 52 (24h) vs 91 (24h)) proved that the water splitting reaction is essential for the catalytic nitrile hydration. The negatively charged nitrogen atom of the coordinated iminolate interacts through a hydrogen bond with a water molecule. Proton transfer from water to the iminolate nitrogen atom generates coordinated iminol and surface coordinating hydroxide unit, which is stabilized by hydrogen bonding with water molecules. The coordinated iminol is successively released from the metal surface and isomerizes to the thermodynamically more stable amide species. Once all surface adsorbed oxygen atoms are converted into hydroxide groups localized on the Pd-NP surface and interconnected with water molecules forming a hydroxide–water layer, the activation of water molecules and the coordination of the nitrile substrate becomes much more difficult to occur. Hence the hydroxide formation on the Pd-NP surface is a real deactivation process in 2-catalyzed nitrile hydration reactions. 2.3.2 Pd(II)-macrocomplex-catalyzed reactions 1-catalyzed nitrile hydration reactions carried out in water at 353K were studied by operando 1H NMR spectroscopy. The effect of coordinated acetate to Pd(II) on the catalytic reaction mechanism was estimated by carrying out the same NMR study with [Pd(OTs)2 L] (1′) which bears the weakly coordinating tosylate (OTs) instead of acetate. Importantly, 1′ showed under the same catalytic conditions, as reported for 1 (Table 1), comparable results (i.e. 84%, 80% (first recycle) and 79% (second recycle)), indicating a negligible effect of the acetate anion on the overall catalytic activity. In Fig. 6 is shown a sequence of 1H NMR spectra of 1 and 1′, acquired under identical experimental conditions. A comparison of the room temperature spectra of 1 and 1′ clearly showed a different 1H NMR pattern for the aromatic bipyridine hydrogen atoms (Fig. 6, traces a and b), which is consistent with the coordination of acetate to Pd(II) at room temperature. 1H NMR spectra of both latter catalysts at 353K, which is the reaction temperature of the catalytic reactions, showed almost identical NMR patterns (Fig. 6, traces c and d), corroborating the fast anion exchange in both latter complexes with D2O, generating hence charged Pd(II)–water species. In the presence of the nitrile substrate (i.e. valeronitrile) an equilibrium between Pd(II) species bearing water molecules and valeronitrile (i.e. 1H NMR signals with an asterisk) coordinating typically with the nitrogen atom is observed with both Pd(II) catalyst precursors at 353K (Fig. 6, traces e and f). This latter equilibrium is strongly shifted toward the Pd–nitrile species, proving the strong coordination properties of the nitrile functionality to Pd(II). The Pd(II)-based catalytic nitrile hydration in water as reaction medium is sketched in Scheme 3 . The Pd(II) precursor species 1 and 1′ are activated at 353K upon dissociation of the anion and coordination of water molecules forming a charged Pd(II)-aqua complex (Scheme 3, step a). Accordingly the 1H NMR spectra of the latter precatalysts showed the same NMR pattern for the 2,2′-bipyridine moiety at 353K in D2O (Fig. 6, traces c and d). The cationic Pd(II)–aqua complex react with the nitrile substrate leading to a Pd(II)-bis-nitrile species which is in equilibrium with the former species (step b) as proved by the operando 1H NMR spectra shown in Fig. 6 traces e and f. The partial substitution of nitrile by water gives the Pd(II)–nitrile–water complex (step c), which is transformed, anion-assisted, into the Pd(II)-hydroxy-nitrile species (step d), which is a key species of the catalytic cycle. The attack of the coordinated hydroxide anion on the cis-coordinated nitrile is mandatory, yielding the Pd-iminolate species (step e). A kinetic study carried out on isolated Pd(II)–OH species bearing 2,2′-bipyridine as ligand [43] confirmed this latter finding. The strong coordination of hydroxide to Pd(II) slows down the migration process. In this respect, a ligand-assisted water activation, without formation of free hydroxide, as described for Ru(acac)2(PPh2Py)2 (acac=acetylacetonate) notably increases the catalytic performance [29]. The protonation of the Pd-iminolate by HX (X=OAc− or OTs−) (i.e. HX is more acidic then coordinated H2O) yields the coordinated iminol (step f), which dissociates from metal centre (step g) and tautomerizes to the amide (step h). 3 Conclusions 2,2′bipyridine end-functionalized poly(ethyleneglycol) methylether was employed to stabilize small Pd-nanoparticles (NPs) (2.0nm), partially covered with chemisorbed oxygen atoms, and Pd-acetate. Both types of catalyst were used to catalyze the selective hydration of nitriles to the corresponding amide under identical experimental conditions (i.e. reactions in water at 353K). Based on normalized TON values, the Pd-NP-based catalyst exhibited on one hand a much higher catalytic activity compared to the molecular counterpart, outperforming related heterogeneous catalysts such as Pd on carbon [17] or Ag on SiO2 [19] (i.e. reaction temperatures >403K), reaching TON-values observed for Au on TiO2 (i.e. reaction temperatures 333–353K) [18]. On the other hand, the Pd-NP-based catalyst experienced a strong deactivation during the first catalytic run, which was rationalized with the conversion of chemisorbed oxygen atoms, which assists the water activation step, into an hydroxide-water layer, located on the Pd-NPs’ surface. Once all chemisorbed oxygen is converted to Pd(II) strongly coordinating hydroxide ions, the positive effect of the oxygen-assisted water activation vanishes and a less efficient reaction mechanism similar to that postulated for the Pd-acetate catalyst becomes operative. 4 Experimental 4.1 Chemicals Poly(ethyleneglycol) monomethyl ether (Mn =5000 gmol−1), methanesulfonyl chloride, dichloromethane, DMF, NaH, Pd(OAc)2, p-TsOH monohydrate, n-hexane, diethyl ether, and 4′-methyl-(2,2′-bipyridine)-4-yl-methanol were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. 4.2 Physical measurements 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance II DRX 300 spectrometer at 300.13MHz. Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm relative to TMS. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Varian-Cary 4000 UV–vis spectrometer, using water solutions with a concentration of 3mgmL−1. The measurements were performed in a quartz cuvette with a 10mm optical path length. TEM analyses were carried out on a TEM PHILIPS CM 12 instrument, equipped with an OLYPMPUS Megaview G2 camera and using an accelerating voltage of 80keV. Samples suitable for the analyses were prepared by depositing a drop of a CH2Cl2 solution of the corresponding sample on a holey film of a 300mesh Cu grid, followed by evaporation of the solvent at room temperature. XPS spectra were acquired at room temperature in normal emission geometry, using a 120mm hemispherical electron energy analyzer (PSP) and a conventional Mg Kα1,2 (1253.6eV) X-ray source, with an overall experimental energy resolution of ∼0.8eV. Binding energies were calibrated by fixing the C 1s signal stemming from atmospheric contaminants at 284.6eV. All spectra were normalized to the incident photon flux and analyzed by performing a nonlinear mean square fit of the data in the binding energy range of interest, following the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm. We used a Shirley background [52] and reproduced the photoemission lineshape of the Pd 3d levels using asymmetric and symmetric Doniach–Sijunich curves for Pd(0) and Pd(II), respectively [53]. GC-analyses were performed with a Shimadzu 2010 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and a 30m (0.25mm i.d., 0.25μm film thickness) VF-WAXms capillary column. GC–MS-analyses were performed with a Shimadzu QP 5000 apparatus, equipped with a 30m (0.32mm i.d., 0.50μm film thickness) CP-WAX 52CB WCOT-fused silica column. ICP-OES analysis was carried out on a iCAP 6200 Duo Thermofisher instrument. 4.3 Syntheses 4.3.1 Synthesis of L Mesyl–PEG–OMe (5.00g, 0.99mmol), which was synthesized as described elsewhere [37], was dissolved in anhydrous DMF (30.0mL). To this solution was added 4′-methyl-(2,2′-bipyridin)-4-yl)-methanol (2.18g, 10.9mmol) and NaH (2.4g, 99.0mmol) and the resulting suspension was stirred at 308K for 24h. The resulting suspension was then filtered and to the clear solution was added diethyl ether (200.0mL) to precipitate the product as off-white solid which was separated by filtration, dried in vacuum and used without further purification. Yield: 3.84g, 75%. 1H NMR (300.13MHz, D2O, 294K): δ =2.72 (s, 3H, CH3), 3.30 (s, 3H, OCH3), 3.61 (br s, 456H, CH2CH2O) 4.71 (s, 2H, CH2O), 7.35 (br s, 1H, ArH), 7.48 (br s, 1H, ArH), 7.88 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.98 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.44 (br s, 1H, ArH), 8.56 (br s, 1H, ArH). 4.3.2 Synthesis of 1 Pd(OAc)2 (47.0mg, 0.120mmol) and L (1.00g, 0.190mmol) were dissolved in anhydrous CH2Cl2 (10.0mL) and the resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 3h. Upon addition of n-hexane (50.0mL), the product precipitated as dark brown solid which was separated by filtration and dried by vacuum. Yield: 0.74g, 72%. 1H NMR (300.13MHz, D2O, 294K): δ =1.84 (s, 3H, CH3CO2), 1.97 (br s, 3H, CH3CO2), 2.44 (br s, 3H, CH3), 3.26 (s, 3H, OCH3), 3.58 (br s, 456H, CH2CH2O) 4.73 (s, 2H, CH2O), 7.40 (br s, 1H, ArH), 7.51 (br s, 1H, ArH), 7.89 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.98 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.08 (br s, 1H, ArH), 8.15 (br s, 1H, ArH). 4.3.3 Synthesis of 1′ 1 (400.0mg, 0.0729mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (4.3.3.1 10.0mL). To the latter solution was added p-TsOH monohydrate (28.4mg, 0.4.3.3.1 149mmol), which dissolved upon reaction. After stirring the solution for 4h, n-hexane (10.0mL) was added, which caused the precipitation of the product as light brown powder, which was separated from solution by filtration and dried by vacuum. Yield: 366.3mg, 0.0620mmol. 1H NMR (300.13MHz, D2O, 294K): δ =2.27 (s, 6H, CH3(tosylate)), 2.54.3.3.1 1 (br s, 3H, CH3), 3.29 (s, 3H, OCH3), 3.64.3.3.1 1 (br s, 456H, CH2CH2O) 4.78 (s, 2H, CH2O), 7.23 (d, 3J(H,H)=6.9Hz, 4H, ArH(tosylate)), 7.47 (br s, 4.3.3.1 1H, ArH), 7.57 (d, 3J(H,H)=6.9Hz, 5H, ArH(tosylate)+ArH), 7.94 (br s, 4.3.3.1 1H, ArH), 8.07 (br s, 2H, ArH), 8.4.3.3.1 16 (s, 4.3.3.1 1H, ArH). 4.3.4 Synthesis of 2 1 (1.50g, 0.278mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (20.0mL) and then transferred into a teflonated stainless steel autoclave (75.0mL), which was successively sealed and purged with hydrogen. Afterward the autoclave was pressurized with hydrogen (15bar) and the solution stirred at room temperature for 12h. Then the hydrogen pressure was released and the black solution concentrated to dryness. The obtained black solid was suspended in diethyl ether (10.0mL), filtered and dried by vacuum at room temperature. The dark brown solid was used without further purification. Yield: 1.40g, 93%. Pd content: 2.0wt%. 4.4 Catalytic nitrile hydration in water Catalyst (50.0mg, 0.009mmol of Pd) and substrate (0.50mmol) were dissolved in water (milliQ-grade) and transferred into a pyrex vial. The obtained suspension was stirred at 353K in air atmosphere for the desired time. Afterward, the obtained solution was cooled to 273K and extracted with diethyl ether (3×2.0mL). To the unified organic phases was added toluene (50.0μL) as internal standard. The obtained solution was objected to GC and GC–MS analysis. The catalyst was recovered after diethyl ether extraction by precipitation with iso-propanol, filtration and drying by vacuum at room temperature. The recovered catalyst was then used for recycling experiments. 4.5 Variable-temperature 1H NMR spectroscopy 1 and 1′ (15.0mg) were separately dissolved in D2O (1.3mL). The obtained solutions were transferred under nitrogen in 5.0mm NMR tubes, sealed and inserted in the NMR probe, followed by the acquisition of 1H NMR spectra at room temperature. Afterward, the samples were heated to 353K, followed by the acquisition of 1H NMR spectra. The NMR samples were cooled to room temperature and removed from the NMR probe. At the latter temperature was added valeronitrile (25.0μL) to the D2O solutions of 1 and 1′, followed by sealing the NMR tubes, inserting in the probe and heating them to 353K. 1H NMR spectra at the latter temperature were acquired for 6h in a time interval of 1h. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance of small Pd-nanoparticles (NPs) (2.0nm), partially covered by chemisorbed oxygen atoms, and of Pd-acetate, both stabilized by 2,2′-bipyridine-end functionalized poly(ethyleneglycol) monomethylether was compared in the selective hydration of nitriles to amide in water under mild reaction conditions (353K). Regardless of the nitrile substrate employed, the Pd-NP-based catalyst showed much higher normalized TON-values (i.e. refereeing to the amount of surface Pd atoms) compared to the Pd(II) macrocomplex, as far as the first catalytic run was considered. Deactivation of the Pd-NP-based catalyst was significant due to the formation of a hydroxide-water layer on the NPs’ surface.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrile hydration to amide in water: Palladium-based nanoparticles vs molecular catalyst
